title: Of the Authority of the Civil Magistrate
text: The King's Majesty hath the chief power in this Realm of England, and other his Dominions ... unto whom the chief government of all estates ... doth appertain ...
commentary: Article 33, “Of the Authority of the Civil Magistrate”, states: The King's Majesty hath the chief power in this Realm of England, and other his Dominions . The commentary below is a concise study essay offering historical context, theological significance, and suggestions for further study. Historically this Article reflects the Reformation effort to retain the catholic tradition where it is scriptural while rejecting practices viewed as unscriptural. For modern readers, note how this Article shapes worship, preaching, and ethical teaching, and compare it with patristic sources and later Anglican commentators.
